sources.full_name: WHO Guidelines for Drinking-water Quality, 4th Edition incorporating 1st & 2nd Addenda
Nigerian Industrial Standard for Drinking Water Quality (NSDWQ)
sources.note: NIS 554:2015 supersedes NIS 554:2007. Limits for priority metals (Pb, As, Cd, Cr, Hg) are harmonised with WHO values.

_metadata.maintainer: Review and update this file whenever WHO or SON publishes a new edition.
_metadata.note: physical_min / physical_max are realistic measurement bounds used for input validation only â€” not compliance limits. Each standard entry carries a 'standard_date' field showing when that authority issued or last revised the limit.

standards.consequence: Below 6.5: pipe corrosion and metallic taste. Above 8.5: scale buildup and reduced disinfection.
standards.solution: Neutralize with Lime (low pH) or Acid Injection (high pH).

standards.consequence: Outside 6.5-8.5: affects taste, chlorine disinfection efficiency, and pipe integrity.
standards.solution: pH adjustment using lime or CO2 injection.

standards.consequence: Interferes with disinfection; aesthetically unpleasing and indicative of contamination.
standards.solution: Coagulation, Flocculation, and Filtration.

standards.consequence: High turbidity shields bacteria from chlorine; reduces disinfection efficacy.
standards.solution: Optimise filtration. For effective chlorination turbidity must be below 1 NTU.

standards.consequence: Salty taste; scale formation in pipes and appliances.
standards.solution: Reverse Osmosis (RO).

standards.consequence: Gastrointestinal irritation; unpalatable water above 1000 mg/L.
standards.solution: Desalination or RO treatment.

standards.consequence: Elevated conductivity indicates high dissolved salts, corrosive potential.
standards.solution: Reverse Osmosis or Ion Exchange.

standards.consequence: Aesthetically unacceptable; may indicate organic matter or metal contamination.
standards.solution: Coagulation-flocculation-filtration or activated carbon treatment.

standards.consequence: Indicative of dissolved organic matter; reduces consumer confidence.
standards.solution: Coagulation and filtration. Investigate source contamination.

standards.consequence: High temperature accelerates bacterial growth and promotes pipe corrosion.
standards.solution: Cool storage; prevent sunlight exposure on water pipes and tanks.

standards.consequence: Low DO indicates organic pollution or anaerobic conditions; promotes H2S odour.
standards.solution: Aeration (cascade or diffuser aerators) to raise DO levels.

standards.consequence: DO below 4 mg/L promotes taste and odour problems and corrosion.
standards.solution: Aeration treatment.

standards.consequence: Taste impairment and corrosion of concrete infrastructure.
standards.solution: Use PVC pipes or apply Reverse Osmosis treatment.

standards.consequence: Laxative effect and diarrhea above 500 mg/L; aesthetic threshold is 250 mg/L.
standards.solution: Reverse Osmosis or Ion Exchange.

standards.consequence: Reddish-brown staining of laundry and fixtures; metallic taste.
standards.solution: Aeration followed by sand filtration.

standards.consequence: Aesthetic nuisance (staining, taste). No formal health-based limit set.
standards.solution: Oxidation and filtration.

standards.consequence: CRITICAL: Neurotoxin causing irreversible brain damage, especially in children.
standards.solution: Coagulation with alum, RO, replace lead service pipes, pH control.

standards.consequence: CRITICAL: Causes kidney damage, hypertension, developmental impairment. No safe level.
standards.solution: Replace lead pipes. Maintain pH > 7.5 to reduce leaching.

standards.consequence: Blue Baby Syndrome (Methemoglobinemia) in infants under 6 months.
standards.solution: Ion Exchange or Reverse Osmosis. DO NOT boil - boiling concentrates nitrates.

standards.consequence: Indicator of agricultural runoff or sewage. Methemoglobinemia risk for infants.
standards.solution: Ion Exchange. Investigate and control fertilizer/sewage runoff source.

standards.consequence: Direct cause of methemoglobinemia. More toxic than nitrate. Indicates recent organic contamination.
standards.solution: Aeration, chlorination, and Ion Exchange. Investigate sewage infiltration.

standards.consequence: Methemoglobinemia risk. Short-term limit. WHO also sets 0.2 mg/L for long-term exposure.
standards.solution: Biological nitrification filter. Chlorination to oxidise nitrite to nitrate.

standards.consequence: Group 1 Carcinogen. Causes skin/lung/bladder cancer and skin lesions.
standards.solution: Activated Alumina adsorption or Coagulation with iron salts.

standards.consequence: Causes Blackfoot disease, peripheral neuropathy, multiple cancers. Chronic exposure.
standards.solution: Adsorption filters (Activated Alumina or Iron-based). RO for severe contamination.

standards.consequence: Dental fluorosis (brown/mottled teeth) above 1.5 mg/L. Skeletal fluorosis above 4 mg/L.
standards.solution: Activated Alumina (Nalgonda Technique) or Bone Char filtration.

standards.consequence: Dental and skeletal fluorosis. Bone deformation with chronic high exposure.
standards.solution: Reverse Osmosis or Activated Alumina defluoridation.

standards.consequence: Gastrointestinal distress (nausea/vomiting) and liver damage at high concentrations.
standards.solution: pH adjustment to reduce pipe corrosivity (keep pH > 7.0).

standards.consequence: Stomach upset, nausea. Liver and kidney damage with chronic high exposure.
standards.solution: Pipe replacement or Ion Exchange. Reduce corrosive conditions.

standards.consequence: Black stains on laundry and plumbing; neurological effects with chronic exposure.
standards.solution: Chemical oxidation with potassium permanganate or chlorine, then filtration.

standards.consequence: Neurological effects (neurotoxicity) with long-term exposure. WHO revised limit downward in 2021.
standards.solution: Greensand filtration or Biological Manganese Removal (BMR) filter.

standards.consequence: Astringent taste and milky appearance above 3 mg/L.
standards.solution: Ion Exchange or flushing of galvanized pipes.

standards.consequence: Scale formation in pipes, boilers, and appliances; high soap consumption.
standards.solution: Water Softening via Lime-Soda process or Ion Exchange.

standards.consequence: CRITICAL: Accumulates in kidneys causing renal tubular damage (Itai-itai disease). Carcinogen.
standards.solution: Coagulation-flocculation, lime softening, or RO. Remove galvanized pipe sources.

standards.consequence: CRITICAL: Long half-life in kidneys. Kidney damage, bone softening, and cancer risk.
standards.solution: Coagulation, Ion Exchange, or RO. Identify and eliminate contamination source.

standards.consequence: Cr(VI) is a known carcinogen. Causes skin sensitisation and lung cancer.
standards.solution: Coagulation at controlled pH, reduction of Cr(VI) to Cr(III), then precipitation.

standards.consequence: Hexavalent Cr is carcinogenic. Causes liver and kidney damage.
standards.solution: Coagulation with ferrous sulphate to reduce Cr(VI) to Cr(III), then flocculation.

standards.consequence: CRITICAL: Powerful neurotoxin. Causes Minamata disease, kidney failure, neurological damage.
standards.solution: Activated carbon adsorption, coagulation, or RO. Source elimination is critical.

standards.consequence: CRITICAL: Inorganic mercury causes kidney toxicity. Organic mercury (methylmercury) is a severe neurotoxin.
standards.solution: Activated carbon adsorption or Ion Exchange. RO for inorganic mercury.

standards.consequence: Causes allergic skin reactions; possible carcinogen with chronic exposure.
standards.solution: Ion Exchange or RO. Check stainless steel fittings for leaching.

standards.consequence: Allergenic. Probable human carcinogen (Group 2A). Kidney and liver damage at high doses.
standards.solution: Ion Exchange, RO, or replacement of nickel-plated plumbing components.

standards.consequence: Cardiovascular effects; increases blood pressure and causes kidney damage.
standards.solution: Ion Exchange, lime softening, or RO.

standards.consequence: Cardiovascular effects (raised blood pressure). WHO revised upward from 0.7 mg/L in 2022.
standards.solution: Ion Exchange or Reverse Osmosis.

standards.consequence: Hair and nail loss (selenosis); liver and nervous system damage.
standards.solution: RO, coagulation at low pH, or Activated Alumina adsorption.

standards.consequence: Chronic excess causes selenosis: hair/nail loss, neurological effects. Essential trace element but toxic above limits.
standards.solution: Reverse Osmosis or Activated Alumina adsorption.

standards.consequence: Inhibits cellular oxygen utilisation. Even low doses cause chronic neurological effects.
standards.solution: Chlorination at high pH (alkaline chlorination) or activated carbon.

standards.consequence: Acute poisoning at high levels. Chronic exposure causes thyroid and neurological damage.
standards.solution: Alkaline chlorination, ozone oxidation, or activated carbon adsorption.

standards.consequence: Salty taste above 250 mg/L. Corrosive to metal pipes and infrastructure.
standards.solution: RO or electrodialysis for high-chloride groundwater.

standards.consequence: No formal health-based limit. Taste threshold ~250 mg/L. Corrosive to distribution systems.
standards.solution: RO treatment. Investigate source (seawater intrusion or industrial discharge).

standards.consequence: Pungent odour; indicator of sewage or agricultural contamination. Reacts with chlorine reducing disinfection.
standards.solution: Breakpoint chlorination or biological nitrification filter. Investigate contamination source.

standards.consequence: No formal health-based guideline. Aesthetic limit of 1.5 mg/L based on odour threshold. Reduces chlorine disinfection efficiency.
standards.solution: Aeration or biological nitrification. Reduce at source.

standards.consequence: Below 0.2 mg/L: insufficient disinfection residual in distribution. Above 0.5 mg/L: taste/odour complaints and DBP risk.
standards.solution: Adjust chlorine dose at treatment plant. Check contact time (min 30 min at pH < 8.0).

standards.consequence: Below 0.5 mg/L after 30 min contact: inadequate disinfection. Above 5 mg/L: taste complaints and disinfection by-products (THMs).
standards.solution: Maintain minimum 0.5 mg/L free chlorine after 30 min contact at pH < 8.0. Maintain residual throughout distribution.

standards.consequence: Reproductive toxicity and developmental effects at high doses.
standards.solution: RO (partial removal only). Ion Exchange with boron-selective resins.

standards.consequence: Disinfection by-product of chlorination. Known carcinogens (chloroform, bromoform). Linked to bladder cancer.
standards.solution: Reduce organic precursors before chlorination. Use alternative disinfectants (ozone, UV). Activate carbon post-treatment.

standards.consequence: Chloroform: possible carcinogen. Chronic exposure linked to liver, kidney, and bladder cancer.
standards.solution: Remove Natural Organic Matter (NOM) before disinfection. Consider ozonation or UV.

standards.consequence: FECAL CONTAMINATION CONFIRMED: Immediate Cholera, Typhoid, and dysentery risk.
standards.solution: Immediate Disinfection with Chlorine (boil water advisory). Investigate source of contamination.

standards.consequence: FECAL CONTAMINATION: Direct indicator of pathogenic risk. Water pathogenically unsafe.
standards.solution: Emergency chlorination. Do not distribute water. Inspect entire system integrity.

standards.consequence: Indicates environmental or fecal contamination of the distribution system.
standards.solution: Check system integrity for pipe cracks. Shock-chlorinate distribution system.

standards.consequence: Should be absent in treated piped water. Presence indicates treatment failure.
standards.solution: Disinfection. Audit treatment process (filtration + chlorination). Inspect network for intrusion.

standards.consequence: High HPC indicates general microbial activity and possible biofilm growth in distribution pipes.
standards.solution: Improve chlorine residual in distribution. Clean and flush pipe network.

standards.consequence: Indicator of treatment efficiency and biological stability. Not directly pathogenic but signals system issues.
standards.solution: Maintain adequate chlorine residual. Investigate stagnation points in distribution.
